Editor’s choice paper Cu nanoparticles decorated Cu organic framework based efficient and reusable heterogeneous catalyst for coupling reactions Poonam Rani a Prem Felix Siril b Rajendra Srivastava a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology Ropar, Rupnagar, 140001, India Department of Chemistry Indian Institute of Technology Ropar Rupnagar 140001 India b School of Basic Sciences, Indian Institute of Technology Mandi, Mandi, 75005, Himanchal Pradesh, India School of Basic Sciences Indian Institute of Technology Mandi Mandi Himanchal Pradesh 75005 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Cu nanoparticles decorated metal organic framework was successfully synthesized and investigated in the eco-friendly and sustainable synthesis of indolizine and chalcone using phenyl acetylene as one of the building block. Cu based metal organic frameworks were prepared and investigated as heterogeneous catalysts in the multi-component coupling reaction involving phenylacetylene as one of the building block for the synthesis of indolizine. Using the same set of reactants, chalcone was synthesized in neat condition. To enhance the catalytic activity and selectivity, Cu nanoparticles decorated Cu based metal organic framework was prepared using NaBH4 as reducing agent and sodium dodecyl sulfate as capping agent. Materials were characterized by the complementary combination of X-ray diffraction, N2-adsorption, scanning/transmission electron microscopic technique, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, UV–vis spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and electrochemical method. For comparative purpose, Cu cluster compound and CuO were also prepared. Recycling and leaching experiments were performed to demonstrate the sustainability and robustness of the catalytic system. A wide range of indolizine and chalcones were prepared in high yields using this catalyst. Keywords Cu nanoparticles Metal organic framework Phenylacetylene Indolizine Chalcone 1 Introduction Development of new class of porous material is advantageous in numerous inter-disciplinary research areas [1]. Porous materials especially zeolites play significant role in the heterogeneous catalysis. However, their application is limited in wide range of organic transformations because of inability to incorporate transition metals in their framework structure [2]. Due to the difference in ionic radius and charge of transition metals when compared to Si, it is difficult to incorporate wide range of transition metals in inorganic zeolite framework. In recent time efforts are being made to develop metal organic frameworks (MOF) in which various metals can be incorporated in the MOF framework [3]. MOFs also known as porous coordination polymers received considerable interest in recent time because of their novel three dimensional porous structures. The combination of inorganic and organic building blocks into highly ordered crystalline structures offers large number of combination, enormous flexibility in pore size, shape and structure, and plenty opportunities for functionalization, grafting and encapsulation [4]. These characteristics make them a promising candidate for a variety of applications including catalysis, chemical separation, sensing, gas storage and drug delivery [5]. Although MOFs have been initially developed for the storage and separation of small gas molecules (such as H2, CO2, CH4 etc.), they could be easily utilized in numerous applications as mentioned above. Tunable porous architecture and metal atoms are important for the storage of large amount of gas molecules mentioned above [6]. Availability of interesting transition metals and large variety of organic linkers are important for the development of wide variety of MOFs. Redox property of transition metals along with porous architecture is key features that enable them to act as interesting catalysts [7]. However, several MOFs are found to be unstable. Their framework collapses upon long time storage or moisture exposure or thermal breakdown even at low temperature [8]. Only a few MOFs can be explored for sustainable catalysis due to their high stability. There are various ways to increase the catalytic application of MOFs like post synthetic modification [9], functionalization of organic linker by active sites [10], introduction of structural defects [11], solvent exchange [12], etc. In recent time, significant efforts have been made to develop catalytic process based on Cu-MOF such as cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide [13], decarboxylation of oleic acid [14], oxidation of benzyl alcohols and aromatic compounds [15,16], cyanosilylation of benzaldehyde [17], C-X (where X=N,C) coupling reactions [18,19], ring opening of epoxide [20,21], hydroamination [21], and condensation reactions [22]. Another important feature of MOFs (in addition to the diverse chemical composition) is their large surface area and porosity compared to other related micro- and mesoporous materials. Therefore, MOF can act as active support material for the loading of metal nanoparticles. In recent time, efforts are being made to develop metal nanoparticles supported MOF materials for wide range of catalytic applications [23]. Metal incorporation in MOF framework structure itself imparts catalytic activity; therefore, incorporation of metal nanoparticles will enable us to synthesize multi-functional catalysts. In general, efforts have been made to develop nanoparticles of various noble metals such as platinum, gold, ruthenium, palladium, and iridium [24]. However, the high cost of these nanoparticles restricts their future prospective in the industrial applications as catalyst. For this reason, efforts are being made to develop less expensive Cu and Ni nanoparticles based catalyst systems [25–29]. In this study, three Cu based MOFs were prepared. For comparative study, one Cu cluster compound was also prepared. In this study, copper nanoparticles decorated MOFs were prepared. Pre-synthesized sodium dodecyl sulfate capped Cu nanoparticles were loaded on the external surface of MOFs to prepare copper nanoparticles decorated MOFs. Copper nanoparticles decorated Cu-MOFs were investigated in the sustainable, one-pot coupling reaction involving phenyl acetylene as building block for the synthesis of indolizines. Using the same set of reactants, it was possible to synthesize chalcone under neat condition. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation In this study, three Cu based MOFs (Cu-BTC-MOF [30], Cu-BDC-MOF [31], and Cu-BDC-DABCO-MOF [32]) were prepared. For comparative study, one Cu cluster compound Cu4I4(DABCO)2 was also prepared [18]. Details of their synthesis are provided in supporting information section. For the preparation of Cu nanoparticles decorated MOFs, first Cu nanoparticles colloidal solution was prepared. In a typical synthesis of Cu nanoparticles, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.57g) was dissolved in 150mL of ethanol and stirred at 2–3°C for 10min to get solution A. In a separate flask, sodium dodecyl sulfate (0.93g) and reducing agent sodium borohydride (0.55g) were dissolved in 100mL ethanol and was stirred at 2–3°C for 10min to get solution B. Then the solution A was slowly added into solution B and the resultant solution was stirred at 2–3°C for 30min. Resultant reaction mixture was kept under ambient condition for 45min. The resultant solution became black due to the formation of Cu nanoparticles. In another beaker, MOF (1.5g) was dispersed in 50mL of ethanol. The dispersed MOF was then added to the colloidal Cu nanoparticles solution at ambient temperature and kept under stirring condition for 5h. The resulting product was centrifuged, washed with ethanol and dried at 100°C for 12h to obtain 10wt% Cu nanoparticles decorated MOF materials. Different amount (wt%) of Cu nanoparticles were loaded on Cu-BTC-MOF and they are represented as Cu(x%)/Cu-BTC-MOF, where x is the weight% of Cu loaded. For comparative purpose CuO also prepared by following the reported procedure [33]. Cu(10%)/CuO was prepared by following the method described above. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded in the 2θ range of 5–60° with a scan speed of 2°/min on a PANalytical X’PERT PRO diffractometer, using Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.1542nm, 40kV, 40mA) and a proportional counter detector. Nitrogen adsorption measurements were performed at 77K by Quantachrome Instruments, Autosorb-IQ volumetric adsorption analyzer. Sample was out-gassed at 150°C for 3h in the degas port of the adsorption apparatus. The specific surface area was calculated from the adsorption data points obtained at P/P0 between 0.05–0.3 using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. The pore diameter was estimated using the Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. Scanning electron microscopy measurements (SEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) were carried out on a JEOL JSM-6610LV to investigate the morphology and chemical composition of the MOF. The detailed structural analysis of the developed morphologies were carried out by TEM using FEI Tecnai G2 200 S-Twin Model (200kV) on carbon coated copper grids. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker spectrophotometer in the region 400–4000cm−1 (spectral resolution=4cm−1; number of scans=100. Diffused reflectance UV–vis (DR UV–vis) spectra were recorded on Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer using BaSO4 as reference material. X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out using Thermo K-alpha instrument. Cyclic voltammetry was carried out on a computer-controlled electrochemical analyzer (Autolab PGSTAT302N potentiostat–galvanostat) at ambient temperature in 0.10M phosphate buffer (pH 6.0). Bare or MOF-modified glassy carbon (GC) electrodes were used as working electrodes, platinum wire as counter electrode and Ag/AgCl (KCl-saturated) electrode as reference electrode. To prepare the MOF-modified electrodes, 2mg of the as-prepared samples was dispersed into 2mL ethanol using sonicator to give homogeneous suspension. A 5μL of the suspension was drop-casted onto GC electrode and the electrode was then dried at ambient temperature. 2.3 Procedure for catalytic reactions 2.3.1 Indolizine synthesis A two neck round-bottomed flask was charged with 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (1.0mmol), base (1.0mmol), phenylacetylene (1.0mmol) and solvent (4mL). Catalyst (40mg) was added to the reaction mixture and reaction flask was placed in a temperature-controlled oil bath. The reaction flask was attached to a water-cooled condenser. The reaction was conducted at 70°C for a desired period of time. Progress of the reaction was monitored by gas chromatograph (GC) (Yonglin 6100; BP-5; 30m×0.25mm×0.25μm). Product was confirmed using GC–MS (Schimadzu GCMS-QP 2010 Ultra; Rtx-5 Sil Ms; 30m×0.25mm×0.25μm). 2.3.2 Chalcone synthesis A two neck round-bottomed flask was charged with 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (1.0mmol), base (1.0mmol) and phenylacetylene (1.0mmol). Catalyst (40mg) was added to the reaction mixture and reaction flask was placed in a temperature-controlled oil bath. The reaction flask was attached to a water-cooled condenser. The reaction was conducted at 70°C for a desired period of time. Progress of the reaction was monitored by GC and the products were identified by GC–MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physico-chemical characterization Powder XRD patterns of various catalysts prepared in this study are shown in Fig. 1 . XRD pattern of Cu-BTC-MOF (Fig. 1a) matches well with the XRD pattern of HKUST-1 reported in the literature [30]. For comparative study, two other Cu based MOFs such as Cu-BDC-MOF & Cu-BDC-DABCO-MOF and one Cu cluster compound Cu4I4(DABCO)2 were prepared. XRD patterns of Cu-BDC-MOF and Cu-BDC-DABCO-MOF catalysts match well with the reported XRD patterns (Fig. 1b) [31,32]. Cu nanoparticles were decorated on the surface of Cu-BTC-MOF. XRD pattern of Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF is similar to that of Cu-BTC-MOF (Fig. 1a). However, distinguished diffraction patterns corresponding to CuNPs are not observed possibly due to small size of CuNPs. Furthermore, the XRD peak intensities of Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF decreased compared to those of Cu-BTC-MOF which are due to the partial occupation of Cu nanoparticles in the matrix of MOF and the partial destruction of the crystalline framework of the MOF during the synthesis of CuNPs. Textural property of the material was investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements. As-synthesized Cu-BTC-MOF (without solvent exchange) exhibits type I isotherm which suggests that the synthesized Cu-BTC-MOF is a microporous material (Fig. 2 a). After solvent exchange, a somewhat flat adsorption curve is observed for Cu-BTC-MOF in the range of 0.1–0.6 (P/P0), but the hysteresis loop at high P/P0 in the range of 0.7–1.0 in the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm shows type-IV behaviour (Fig. 2b). The obtained isotherm shows the presence of both micropores and mesopores. Change in the isotherm indicates that crystal collapse and partial loss of crystallinity takes place during the solvent-exchange and activation process that leads to form disordered mesopores within the MOF structure. Textural properties obtained from the N2-adsorption study is summarized in Table 1 . Isotherm for Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF is found to be similar to its parent material. However, its pore-size distributions are narrow when compared to their parent materials. This observation confirms that CuNPs would penetrate into the inter-particle mesopores and plug some of these pores. Textural property summarized in Table 1 clearly shows that the loading of CuNPs reduces the surface area and pore volume of the material. Surface morphology was investigated using SEM (Fig. 3 ). Large and small crystals with octahedral morphology are observed in the SEM micrograph of Cu-BTC-MOF. Particle size observed in this study matches well with the literature report [34]. It may be noted that these large particles are built with small nanocrystals as shown below in the TEM investigation. Uniform, nanometer size small particles are observed in the SEM micrograph of Cu-BDC-MOF (Fig. 3). However, non-uniform micrometer size large crystals are observed for Cu-BDC-DABCO-MOF (Fig. 3). Uniform nanometer size particles are observed in the SEM micrograph of Cu4I4(DABCO)2 (Fig. 3). Morphology of Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF crystals are somewhat distorted when it is compared with the morphology of parent Cu-BTC-MOF (Fig. 3). This confirms that outer surface is disturbed under the reducing synthesis condition for the preparation of CuNPs. It may be noted that decrease in the crystallinity is observed in the XRD pattern after the incorporation of CuNPs. This also provides evidence that the reducing NaBH4 environment alters the surface morphology of the parent material. Decoration of CuNPs in the material can be easily observed during TEM investigation. TEM images of Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF taken from the different parts of the specimen clearly show that CuNPs are uniformly coated in the Cu-BTC-MOF matrix. Some of the representative TEM images are shown in Fig. 4 . TEM images clearly show that 2–3nm CuNPs are formed and adhere to the surface of MOF samples after the NaBH4 reduction. TEM images also confirm that large MOF crystals shown in SEM images are actually built with nanometer size small crystals. Materials were characterized with FT-IR and UV–vis spectroscopic techniques. FT-IR spectra of parent and CuNPs decorated MOF materials are shown in Fig. 5 a. The carboxylate asymmetric stretching in Cu-BTC-MOF are observed at 1630cm−1 and 1574cm−1, respectively, while the symmetric stretching of carboxylate group in Cu-BTC-MOF are observed at 1436cm−1 & 1363cm−1, respectively. Several bands in the region of 1300–600cm−1 are observed that are assigned to the out-of-plane (OOP) vibrations of BTC group in framework. FT-IR spectra of CuNPs decorated MOF is similar to that of parent MOF which shows that structure of parent MOFs is preserved after the decoration of CuNPs on MOF. Formation of CuNPs in MOF matrix can also be confirmed using DRUV–vis spectroscopy (Fig. 5b). In general, absorption in the range of 250–450nm is ascribed to the charge transfer band, whereas absorption above 600nm is ascribed to the d–d transition [35]. In addition, absorption above 500nm belongs to the plasmonic resonance of Cun nanoparticles. The absorption spectrum of Cu-BTC-MOF exhibits absorption in two regions, one in the range of 200–400nm and second in the range of 500–1000nm (Fig. 5b). Absorption in the range of 200–400nm is ascribed to charge transfer bands, whereas absorption above 500nm is ascribed to d–d transition. The UV–vis spectrum of Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF is almost similar to that of Cu-BTC-MOF but with some changes in the absorption band in the range of 500–800nm, which confirms the incorporation of CuNPs in the matrix of Cu-BTC-MOF. In order to confirm the presence of different oxidation state of Cu species present in Cu-MOFs and CuNPs supported Cu-BTC-MOF, CV and XPS measurements were performed (Fig. 6 ). CV of Cu-BTC-MOF modified GC electrode in 0.10M phosphate buffer at a scan rate of 50mV/s reveals that Cu-BTC-MOF is electrochemically active and exhibits one pair of well-defined redox wave (oxidation potential of −0.025V and reduction potential of −0.125V) corresponding to redox process of CuII/I in the MOF (Fig. 6a). Different CV was observed for Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF. CV shows that Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF is also electrochemically active and exhibits two pairs of redox peaks (oxidation potentials of 0.007V and 0.108V and reduction potentials of −0.119V and −0.355V) corresponding to the redox process of CuII/I and CuI/0 redox couples (Fig. 6a). CVs of Cu-BDC-MOF and Cu-BDC-DABCO-MOF are similar to that of Cu-BTC-MOF but with high oxidation current response (Fig. 6b), which shows that electron transfer is easily facilitated at the electrode surface for these materials. XPS is a useful technique to verify the oxidation state of the Cu present in the Cu-BTC-MOF and Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF. Fig. 6c shows the high resolution XPS spectrum of Cu (2p) for Cu-BTC-MOF, which exhibits overlapped broad peak in the range of 934–938eV. Actually this broad signature is observed due to the overlapped peaks corresponding to Cu2+ and Cu+ states. High resolution XPS spectrum of Cu (2p) for Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF exhibits two peaks in the range of 930–938eV. First peak corresponds to Cu0 whereas second overlapped peak is due to Cu2+ and Cu+ states. 3.2 Catalytic activity In this study, efforts have been made to demonstrate the application of Cu-MOFs and Cu NPs decorated Cu-MOF in the synthesis of indolizine and chalcone derivatives. These compounds are known to exhibit excellent pharmacological activity and precursors to several important synthetic intermediates. Recently we have shown the application of Cu-MOFs in coupling reactions [18]. We were interested to explore the possibility to use Cu-MOFs in the synthesis of pharmaceutically important indolizines. Indolizine can be prepared by the conventional transition metal catalyzed CN bond forming reaction [36–39]. Very recently, an in-depth study based on the synthesis of indolizine and chalcone is reported using CuNPs supported carbon catalyst [40,41]. In the recent time, efforts are being made to develop sustainable catalysts for the synthesis of indolizines [42–49]. However, our interest is to develop MOF based heterogeneous catalysts based sustainable catalytic process for the synthesis of fine and pharmaceutically important chemicals. Based on our previous experience with Cu-MOF catalyzed coupling reactions, we anticipated that Cu-MOFs could be used in the preparation of indolizines by one-pot multi-component synthesis strategy which allows structural diversity in the sustainable atom-efficient, one-step synthesis route. We started our investigation to find which Cu-MOF would be more suitable for the synthesis of indolizine (Table 2 ). Experiments show that all Cu-MOFs investigated in this study are active for the synthesis of indolizine. In all these cases, indolizine is selectively obtained in CH2Cl2 reaction medium. Cu-MOFs and Cu cluster compound investigated in this study exhibit good activity in the synthesis of indolizine under the optimized reaction condition. Among the Cu-MOFs, Cu-BTC-MOF exhibits the highest yield for indolizine (Table 2). In order to improve the yield of product, CuNPs were supported on the surface of Cu-BTC-MOF. Metal content was systematically varied to enhance the reactivity and selectivity of the desired product. It is known in the literature that Cu metal nanoparticles are important to catalyze these reactions [40,41]; therefore Cu content (2%, 5%, 7.5%, 10%, and 12.5%) was systematically varied. However, the catalytic results are shown here for only three samples, Cu(2%)/Cu-BTC-MOF, Cu(5%)/Cu-BTC-MOF, and Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF in this manuscript. Because the results obtained using Cu(7.5%)/Cu-BTC-MOF was slightly lower than that of Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF and the results obtained using Cu(12.5%)/Cu-BTC-MOF was almost similar or little lower than that of Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF. Different amount of CuNPs were loaded on Cu-BTC-MOF. With increase in the amount of CuNPs content, catalytic activity increases (Table 2). Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF exhibits the highest activity for the synthesis of indolizine under the optimized reaction condition. To evaluate the robustness of the catalytic systems, Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF was recycled. No significant change in the activity was observed even after five recycles (Table 2). Leaching experiments further confirm that conversion did not increase even after the removal of the catalyst. ICP analysis shows that <2ppm of Cu leached to the solution during recycling study. XRD and N2-adsorption studies show that recycled catalyst was stable and no appreciable change in the textural properties were observed (Table 1). Based on the recycling and leaching experiments one can conclude that Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF is found to be sustainable and robust catalysts for the synthesis of indolizine. CuO is also found to be active for the synthesis of indolizine but the reaction is not very selective towards the formation of indolizine (Chalcone is formed as side product) (Table 2). Activity and selectivity of Cu(10%)/CuO is more when compared to CuO, however it is lower than that of Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF. This provides evidence that oxidation state of Cu in Cu-MOFs is more suitable for the formation of indolizine. Although Cu2+, Cu+, and Cu0 all have capability to activate phenylacetylene but the capability to activate phenylacetylene is more for Cu+ and Cu0, therefore Cu-MOFs and Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF are more active and selective towards the formation of indolizine. Since CuO contains only Cu2+ therefore its activity is somewhat lower than Cu-MOFs investigated in this study. Furthermore, CuO possesses weak acidity that is responsible for the formation of chalcone as side product. Influence of solvent in the synthesis of indolizine was investigated with Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF and data is presented in Table S1. Reaction did not proceed in toluene or 1,4-dioxane. Very low yield of indolizine is obtained in the protic solvent such as methanol and THF (Table S1). However, only indolzine is obtained as selective product in methanol. Polar aprotic solvents such as CH2Cl2 and CH3CN were investigated. Catalytic data shows that CH2Cl2 is more effective and produced indolizine as selective product in excellent yield. However, using CH3CN, 2-pyridine carboxaldehyde conversion is high but the indolizine selectivity is low. In this case, in addition to chalcone, some amount of diphenylene diacetylene is also obtained. An interesting result was obtained when the reaction was performed in neat condition. In this case, very low selectivity for indolizine was obtained but it produce large amount of chalcone. In order to see the general applicability of this protocol for wide range of amine derivatives, primary, secondary and tertiary amines were investigated (Table 3 ). Tertiary amine such as triethyl amine is found to be inactive under the optimized reaction condition (Table 3). Reaction proceeds well with various secondary amines such as piperidine, pyrrolidine, and diethyl amine. In all these cases corresponding indolizine product is obtained (Table 3). When primary amine such as butyl amine is reacted under the optimized reaction condition, indolizine is not obtained. In this case, condensation product of 2-pyridine carboxaldehyde and n-butyl amine is obtained (Table 3). Wide range of phenyl acetylenes and secondary amines can be converted to the corresponding indolizines with good to excellent yield (Table 3). Comparative catalytic activity data shows that this catalyst exhibits higher or comparable catalytic activity when compared to various catalysts reported in the literature for the synthesis of indolizine (Table S2). Based on the results obtained and literature report [41,49], plausible mechanism for the synthesis of indolizine is shown in Scheme S1. The multi-component synthesis of indolizine is mediated through iminium ion (I) and Cu-acetylide (II). Iminium ion is formed by the condensation of amine (piperidine) and aldehyde (pyridine 2-carboxaldeyde). Whereas, framework substituted Cu in Cu-MOF or CuNPs activate the phenylacetylene acidic proton by the coordination to CC to form Cu-acetylide. Activated phenylacetylene carbon centre reacts with imine and form intermediate (III), which upon cycloisomerization (facilitated by lone pair electrons of pyridine) through intermediate (IV) and aromatization in the presence of Cu catalyst to produce indolizine as the selective product. Our initial investigation gave clear evidence that this catalyst can be used to synthesize chalcone derivative from phenylacetylene if the reaction is performed in the absence of solvent. Since chalcone is also very important synthetic intermediate therefore detail investigation was made for the synthesis of chalcone using various catalysts investigated in this study. Using Cu-BTC-MOF and Cu-BDC-MOF, in addition to chalcone and indolizine, diphenyl-diacetylene is also formed (Table 4 ). Whereas using Cu-BDC-DABCO-MOF, chalcone and indolizine are obtained under the same reaction condition (Table 4). Cu cluster compound is also active and produced three products, chalcone, indolizine, and diphenyl-diacetylene. Based on the results obtained using Cu-MOFs and Cu cluster compound, one can say that Cu-BTC-MOF exhibits higher selectivity towards chalcone (Table 4). CuNPs decorated Cu-BTC-MOF exhibits significantly higher selectivity towards chalcone. With increase in CuNPs content, chalcone selectivity increases. Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF exhibits the highest activity and selectivity for the synthesis of chalcone under the optimized reaction condition (Table 4). When the similar reaction was performed using CuO, chalcone (70.8% selectivity) was obtained along with 2, 2′-bipiperidine (29.2%). Cu(10%)/CuO exhibits better activity than CuO but produces three products, chalcone (80.3% selectivity), Indolizine (8.2% selectivity), and 2, 2′-bipiperidine (11.5% selectivity). Results obtain using Cu-MOFs and Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF clearly show that Cu0 and Cu+1 would be more suitable for the synthesis of chalcone demonstrating the active role of Cu-acetylide (similar active species are involve in the synthesis of indolizine) in the synthesis of chalcone. Influence of base used in the synthesis of chalcone was also investigated (Table 5 ). It may be noted that triethylamine is found to be inactive for this reaction, whereas primary amine such as butyl amine did not produce chalcone under the optimized condition. In the case of butyl amine, diphenylene diacetylene and condensation product of butyl amine and pyridine 2-carboxaldehyde are obtained (Table 5). Secondary amine is good to assist this reaction to form chalcone. Almost quantitative yield of chalcones are obtained using various secondary amines such as piperidine, pyrrolindine, diethyamine, and dipropylamine. Cu(10%)/Cu-BTC-MOF was recycled in the synthesis of chalcone. Recycling study shows that no significant change in the activity and selectivity is obtained even after five recycles, justifying robustness of the catalyst system (Table 4 and Fig. S1). Comparative catalytic activity data shows that this catalyst exhibits higher or comparable catalytic activity when compared to various catalysts reported in the literature for the synthesis of chalcone (Table S3). Result obtained using primary amine provides evidence that iminium ion produced by the condensation of pyridine 2-carboxaldeyde and secondary amine would certainly participate in the reaction mechanism. Since the selectivity of products completely changed from indolizine to chalcone when the reaction is performed in neat condition, therefore it gives clear evidence that in this case different mechanistic pathway is followed. In this case, secondary amine plays very important role. Since amine moiety is not the part of product structure, therefore it is believed that secondary amine acts as a source (for the formation of iminium ion) and suitable base in this reaction. It seems that unsolvated secondary amine proves to be an efficient base that changes the mechanistic pathway leading to chalcone. First few steps are the same as outlined in the proposed mechanism for the synthesis of indolizine (Scheme S1). In this case also it is mediated with the same intermediates (I and II) as shown in the proposed mechanism for the synthesis of indolizine and form pyridinyl propargylamine (III). However, due to strong basisity of unsolvated secondary amines, it has capability to abstract proton from pyridinyl propargylamine. The negative inductive effect produced by the electron withdrawing group increased the acidity of proton attached to propargyl hydrogen atom and stabilizes the negative charge produced after the deprotonation of propargyl-allenyl amine intermediate (IV). Hydrolysis of the intermediate takes place by the H2O formed in the initial conduction step to form chalcone through intermediate (V) (Scheme S2). 4 Conclusions Cu nanoparticles decorated Cu based metal organic framework catalysts were successfully prepared. Physicochemical characterization reveals that highly dispersed 2–3nm Cu nanoparticles were supported on the large external surface of metal organic framework. Cu nanoparticles supported Cu-BTC-MOF exhibited excellent activity in the sustainable synthesis of indolizines and chalcones. These compounds were possible to synthesize because acidic proton of phenylacetylene could be easily activated with Cu-MOF/Cu nanoparticles decorated Cu-MOF. Medium of the reaction plays important role in the selective synthesis of indolizine/chalcone. When CH2Cl2 was used as solvent, indolizine was selectivity obtained whereas in neat condition chalcone was selectively obtained. Cu-MOF exhibited better activity when compared to Cu cluster compound. Catalyst can be easily recycled and exhibited negligible loss in the activity even after five recycles. High reactivity of Cu nanoparticles decorated Cu-MOF can be attributed to the highly dispersed small Cu nanoparticles that could be easily accessible to large reactant molecules and the facile diffusion of product molecules from the active centers through inter/intra-crystalline mesopores of MOF. Disordered mesopores and large external surface area both are important for the facile diffusion of reactants to the active sites and the desorption of product molecules from the active sites that enable the active sites further available for the reaction and make the catalyst recyclable and sustainable. coredata.dc:description: Cu based metal organic frameworks were prepared and investigated as heterogeneous catalysts in the multi-component coupling reaction involving phenylacetylene as one of the building block for the synthesis of indolizine. Using the same set of reactants, chalcone was synthesized in neat condition. To enhance the catalytic activity and selectivity, Cu nanoparticles decorated Cu based metal organic framework was prepared using NaBH4 as reducing agent and sodium dodecyl sulfate as capping agent. Materials were characterized by the complementary combination of X-ray diffraction, N2-adsorption, scanning/transmission electron microscopic technique, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, UV–vis spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and electrochemical method. For comparative purpose, Cu cluster compound and CuO were also prepared. Recycling and leaching experiments were performed to demonstrate the sustainability and robustness of the catalytic system. A wide range of indolizine and chalcones were prepared in high yields using this catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Cu nanoparticles decorated Cu organic framework based efficient and reusable heterogeneous catalyst for coupling reactions
